channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2018 The New York Times Company

item.title: Mexico’s New Leader Faces Clash With Trump Over Migrant Caravan
item.media:description: Migrants running from tear gas released by American border patrol agents near the border at Tijuana, Mexico, on Sunday.
item.description: As Andrés Manuel López Obrador takes office on Saturday, he must balance his humanitarian promises with a hope for good relations with the United States.
item.dc:creator: AZAM AHMED and ELISABETH MALKIN

item.title: 3 U.S. Soldiers Killed by Explosion in Afghanistan
item.description: The blast in the city of Ghazni also wounded three more troops and a contractor. It was the single worst loss of life for the U.S. military in Afghanistan this year.
item.dc:creator: NESAR AZADZOI and ROD NORDLAND
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Music Festivals Are Gaining Popularity in Asia. Just Not With Officials.
item.media:description: A nightclub in Hanoi in September. Asia is a growing market for Western-style music festivals.
item.description: Conservative governments have been canceling Western-inspired events, which they see as threats to public safety, political stability or social and religious values.
item.dc:creator: MIKE IVES
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas

item.title: A Journalist Was Killed in Mexico. Then His Colleagues Were Hacked.
item.media:description: Friends and relatives during the funeral Mass of the slain journalist Javier Valdez last year, in Culiacán, Mexico.
item.description: Text messages sent to them were infected with a spyware that the Mexican government bought from an Israeli cyber arms dealer, according to a forensic analysis.
item.dc:creator: AZAM AHMED

item.title: Argentine Prosecutors Consider Charges Against Saudi Crown Prince Ahead of G-20
item.media:description: A man inspects the wreckage of a school bus in Yemen struck in August by a Saudi-led coalition airstrike that killed 26 children and injured 19.
item.description: A prosecutor in Argentina, site of the Group of 20 summit this week, is examining war crimes charges against Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman.
item.dc:creator: DANIEL POLITI and DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity

item.title: Russia-Ukraine Fight Over Narrow Sea Passage Risks Wider War
item.media:description: President Petro O. Poroshenko of Ukraine speaking to lawmakers in Parliament, who on Monday approved a proposal to introduce martial law for 30 days, after Russia seized three Ukrainian ships a day earlier.
item.description: The opening of an overt front at sea introduced an unstable element into what had been a long-running war fought over land in eastern Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: NEIL MacFARQUHAR

item.title: Turkey Searches Saudi-Owned Mansion for Evidence in Khashoggi Case
item.description: Investigators still have not found the remains of Jamal Khashoggi, the dissident who was killed inside the Saudi Consulate in Istanbul.
item.dc:creator: CARLOTTA GALL

item.title: Chinese Scientist Claims to Use Crispr to Make First Genetically Edited Babies
item.media:description: A microplate from Chinese scientist He Jiankui’s lab, containing embryos whose genes have been edited. Dr. He’s announcement prompted a statement from a group of 122 scientists condemning his actions as “crazy.”
item.description: The researcher, He Jiankui, offered no evidence or data to back up his assertions. If true, some fear the feat could open the door to “designer babies.”
item.dc:creator: GINA KOLATA, SUI-LEE WEE and PAM BELLUCK

item.title: Square Feet: In Serbia, a Former Military Base Finds a New Role
item.media:description: Philip H. Bay of Clean Earth Capital and his associates at Novi Nis in Serbia, a redevelopment project on a former military base that dates to the Ottoman Empire.
item.media:credit: Marko Risovic for The New York Times
item.description: The site, in the central part of Nis, is bustling with activity as the former army barracks is transformed into a new housing and commercial center.
item.dc:creator: BORYANA DZHAMBAZOVA

item.title: Margaret Thatcher, Ice Cream Pioneer, Is Nominated as Face of £50 Note
item.media:description: Margaret Thatcher in 1987. She studied chemistry at Oxford and worked for a food company before beginning her political career.
item.description: The Bank of England has released a list of 800 scientific figures who could feature on its next redesigned bill. One in particular has raised eyebrows.
item.dc:creator: ILIANA MAGRA

item.title: Jack Ma, China’s Richest Man, Belongs to the Communist Party. Of Course.
item.media:description: Jack Ma, China’s richest man and co-founder of the e-commerce giant Alibaba, in Shanghai this month. He was identified as a member of the Chinese Communist Party by its official newspaper.
item.description: Many business figures join the organization out of expedience. Likewise, the party sees benefits in associating itself with capitalist success stories.
item.dc:creator: LI YUAN

item.title: Syrian Refugee, Stranded in Malaysian Airport for Months, Lands in Vancouver
item.media:description: Hassan al-Kontar, second from right, after landing in Vancouver on Monday. Mr. Kontar, who had spent seven months at the airport in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia, said he wanted “a hot shower for the rest of the day.”
item.media:credit: Ben Nelms/The Canadian Press, via Associated Press
item.description: Hassan al-Kontar, who was wanted in Syria for refusing to serve in the military, documented his extended airport stay on social media.
item.dc:creator: DANIEL VICTOR

item.title: Honduran President’s Brother, Arrested in Miami, Is Charged With Drug Trafficking
item.media:description: Juan Antonio Hernández, the brother of Honduras’s president, was accused by American prosecutors of being involved in “large-scale” drug trafficking into the United States for over a decade.
item.description: Juan Antonio Hernández, the brother of the Honduran president, was described as a “large-scale drug trafficker” with ties to organized crime and cocaine deliveries to the United States.
item.dc:creator: JEFF ERNST and ELISABETH MALKIN

item.title: Facing Attack, George Soros’s Foundation Will Shut Down in Turkey
item.media:description: The homepage for the website of Open Society Foundations, George Soros’s philanthropic group.
item.description: Open Society Foundations plans to close its office in Istanbul. It claims that the Turkish government has falsely accused it of playing a role in uprisings.
item.dc:creator: SARAH MERVOSH

item.title: Pain and Sense of Betrayal as Canada G.M. Factory Closes After a Century
item.media:description: Murals depicting the long history of the local auto industry in Oshawa, Ontario.
item.media:credit: Ian Willms for The New York Times
item.description: “Just as you’re getting older to know that you don’t have a job, it’s really heart wrenching,” said a worker at the vast complex in Oshawa, Ontario, where families worked for G.M. for generations.
item.dc:creator: IAN AUSTEN

item.title: Trump Disparages Brexit Deal, Blindsiding May
item.media:description: Prime Minister Theresa May of Britain arriving at 10 Downing Street in London on Monday. Mrs. May must convince Parliament to accept a withdrawal agreement approved by the European Union’s members.
item.description: President Trump called the agreement “a great deal for the E.U.,” and warned that, if adopted, it might obstruct a free trade deal between the U.S. and Britain.
item.dc:creator: ELLEN BARRY

item.title: Climate Change, Paul Manafort, Mars Landing: Your Monday Evening Briefing
item.media:credit: Bryan Tarnowski for The New York Times
item.description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
item.dc:creator: JEAN RUTTER and HIROKO MASUIKE

item.title: Photo of Children Fleeing Tear Gas at Border in Mexico Sparks Anger
item.media:description: Migrants running from tear gas near the U.S.-Mexico border on Sunday after a march in Tijuana, Mexico, veered out of control.
item.description: After a peaceful march veered out of control, an image of a fleeing woman and two children in diapers outraged critics of President Trump’s policies.
item.dc:creator: NIRAJ CHOKSHI

item.title: World’s First Gene-Edited Babies Born This Month, Researcher Says
item.description: The researcher, He Jiankui of China, who claims he helped alter the DNA of twin girls born this month, said the world “has moved on to the stage for embryo gene editing.”

item.title: Have You Worked as a Missionary? We Want to Hear From You
item.media:description: John Allen Chau, an American missionary, was killed last week as he tried to spread Christianity to North Sentinel, a forbidden island in the Andaman Sea with a long history of repelling outsiders.
item.description: The Times would like to better understand how missionaries are reacting to the death of an American missionary, John Allen Chau.
item.dc:creator: THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: Myanmar Dispatch: A General Kicked Off Facebook Can Still Glorify Military at Grandiose Museum
item.media:description: In an exhibition recounting Myanmar’s martial history, the portrait of Senior Gen. Min Aung Hlaing hangs at the top of a pyramid of military leaders.
item.media:credit: Minzayar Oo for The New York Times
item.description: The colossal museum built by Myanmar’s military to honor itself and its leader showcases the mind-set of a force obsessed with its reputation. A critic calls it “a sign of their megalomania.”
item.dc:creator: PAUL MOZUR

item.title: Taiwan Asked Voters 10 Questions. It Got Some Unexpected Answers.
item.media:description: Supporters of same-sex marriage marching in Kaohsiung, Taiwan, on Sunday, after voters expressed overwhelming opposition to same-sex marriage in a referendum.
item.description: The votes may not have turned out the way the governing party wanted, but the referendums themselves served a larger purpose in staving off Beijing’s territorial claim.
item.dc:creator: CHRIS HORTON
item.category: Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships

item.title: Carlos Ghosn Is Removed as Chairman of Mitsubishi Motors
item.media:description: Carlos Ghosn, long admired in Japan for having rescued Nissan, has had a swift fall from grace.
item.description: The board of the Japanese automaker acted a week after Nissan accused Mr. Ghosn of financial misconduct and stripped him of his chairmanship.
item.dc:creator: MOTOKO RICH

item.title: Matthew Hedges, British Student Accused of Spying, Is Pardoned by U.A.E.
item.media:description: Matthew Hedges, who was said to be researching the effects of the Arab Spring on the United Arab Emirates’ approach to diplomacy, was arrested in May.
item.media:credit: Daniele Tajada, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.description: The conviction of Mr. Hedges, and his sentence of life in prison, had been met with outrage in Britain.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL WOLGELENTER and RICHARD PÉREZ-PEÑA

item.title: More Than 140 Whales Die in New Zealand After Mass Beaching
item.description: Such mass beachings can happen when whales make navigational mistakes while chasing prey, escaping predators or trying to protect sick members of the group.
item.dc:creator: CHARLOTTE GRAHAM-McLAY

item.title: As Migrants Try to Cross Border, U.S. Closes It
item.description: Hundreds of migrants tried to evade the police and cross from Tijuana, Mexico, into San Diego. The U.S. Customs and Border Protection Agency responded by firing tear gas and closing the border in both directions. Thousands of migrants from Central America have been living in a shelter in Tijuana.

item.title: Ukraine, After Naval Clash With Russia, Considers Martial Law
item.media:description: Russian jet fighters flying over vessels in the Kerch Strait, a narrow body of water separating the Black and Azov Seas.
item.description: Ukraine said Russia opened fire Sunday on its ships in the Black Sea. The United Nations Security Council is convening an emergency meeting about it.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW E. KRAMER

item.title: Migrants in Tijuana Run to U.S. Border, but Fall Back in Face of Tear Gas
item.media:description: A group of Central American migrants, mostly Hondurans, attempt to climb the first layer of the border fence on Sunday. The fence is heavily fortified in San Diego, often backed by a tall second layer behind a no-man’s land of sensors, cameras and border patrol agents.
item.description: A peaceful march veered out of control as hundreds of migrants tried to evade a Mexican police blockade and reach the border crossing.
item.dc:creator: MAYA AVERBUCH and ELISABETH MALKIN

item.title: Children of North Korean Mothers Find More Hardship in the South
item.media:description: Seon-mi in her dormitory room at Durihana International School in Seoul, a faith-based shelter.
item.media:credit: Jean Chung for The New York Times
item.description: Often born in rural China, the children of North Korean defectors find they are not welcome in South Korea, where they face language barriers and abuse.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Killing of Indigenous Man in Chile Spurs Criticism of Security Forces
item.media:description: The funeral of Camilo Catrillanca in Temucuicui, Chile, this month. The killing of Mr. Catrillanca, 24, by the police has intensified complaints about security forces.
item.description: The killing and a cover-up by the police has intensified anger over a government crackdown against groups fighting to reclaim land.
item.dc:creator: PASCALE BONNEFOY
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: The New New World: How Cheap Labor Drives China’s A.I. Ambitions
item.media:description: Workers at the headquarters of Ruijin Technology Company in Jiaxian, in central China’s Henan Province. They identify objects in images to help artificial intelligence make sense of the world.
item.media:credit: Yan Cong for The New York Times
item.description: If China is the Saudi Arabia of data, its data factories are the refineries, turning raw data into the fuel that can power China’s goal of A.I. supremacy.
item.dc:creator: LI YUAN

item.title: Brexit Deal Has the Backing of E.U. Leaders. What Happens Now?
item.description: Prime Minister Theresa May obtained the approval of the other 27 European Union members for Britain’s divorce from the bloc. But she still has hurdles to overcome at home.
item.dc:creator: ILIANA MAGRA and STEPHEN CASTLE

item.title: Marching to End Violence Against Women
item.media:description: Activists take part in a march on the eve of the commemoration of the International Day for the Elimination of Violence Against Women in Santiago, Chile, on Thursday.
item.description: People around the world are commemorating the U.N.-designated International Day for the Elimination of Violence Against Women.
item.dc:creator: RAPHAEL MINDER, YONETTE JOSEPH and ILIANA MAGRA

item.title: Afghanistan Considers Delaying Presidential Election
item.description: Officials are discussing delaying April 20’s presidential vote amid disarray in counting votes from last month’s parliamentary balloting.
item.dc:creator: ROD NORDLAND and FATIMA FAIZI

item.title: Syria Urges U.N. to Condemn Rebels After Apparent Chemical Attack
item.media:description: A hospital in Aleppo, Syria, on Saturday. Medics reported a flood of patients with breathing troubles, inflamed eyes and other symptoms after a shelling attack in the city.
item.description: Syria accused rebel forces of launching an attack in Aleppo that sent scores of choking victims to hospitals. Medical officials suspected chlorine had been used.
item.dc:creator: BEN HUBBARD

item.title: At Least 31 Die After Boat Sinks in Lake Victoria in Uganda
item.media:description: Ugandan Navy crews joined the recovery effort on Sunday after a boat carrying more than 90 people sank on Lake Victoria.
item.description: The party boat carrying nearly 100 people capsized near Kampala overnight, and the death toll is expected to rise, officials said.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Rio de Janeiro Dispatch: Rio de Janeiro Elevator Attendants ‘Adore’ Their Dying, Chatty Trade
item.media:description: Marcio Martins, an elevator operator at the Banco do Brasil Cultural Center, assisting a visitor.
item.media:credit: Maria Magdalena Arrellaga for The New York Times
item.description: It seemed to be the occupation that automation somehow forgot. But elevator attendants are now losing in droves the jobs they love. When they disappear, so will a sociable slice of the city’s life.
item.dc:creator: ERNESTO LONDOÑO

item.title: E.U. Leaders and U.K. Agree on Brexit Divorce Terms
item.media:description: An abandoned customs post near the Irish border that runs through the town of Pettigo. The border has been a major sticking point in negotiations on Brexit.
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.description: The settlement reached at a summit meeting on Sunday must pass votes in the British Parliament, and leaves deep uncertainties about Britain’s future.
item.dc:creator: STEPHEN CASTLE and STEVEN ERLANGER

item.title: Leda and the Swan: A Fresco Comes to Life in Pompeii Excavation
item.media:description: An ancient fresco depicting the mythical rape of Leda by Zeus in swan form was unearthed in a bedroom of a house under excavation in Pompeii, Italy.
item.media:credit: Cesare Abbate/Pompeii Archaeological Park, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.description: An expensive excavation campaign to shore up an at-risk area of the city is a constant font of archaeological discoveries.
item.dc:creator: ELISABETTA POVOLEDO

item.title: PETA Asks a Village Named Wool to Change Its Name to Vegan Wool
item.media:description: “With a simple name change, your village can take a stand against this cruelty,” Elisa Allen, director of PETA’s London office, wrote, pointing to evidence of mistreatment of sheep on farms around the world.
item.description: When the animal rights group sent a letter asking the English village to take a stand against animal cruelty, residents were surprised, and not amused.
item.dc:creator: PALKO KARASZ
item.category: People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals

item.title: Times Insider: How New York Times Journalists Took the Measure of China’s Rising Power
item.media:description: Workers on an automotive assembly line at the Geely’s Chunxiao Plant in the Beilun District of Zheijiang Province, China. Geely, one of China’s largest automotive manufacturers, has been growing rapidly in the past decade.
item.media:credit: Bryan Denton for The New York Times
item.description: A Q. and A. with our managing editor, Joe Kahn, about the China Rules series.
item.dc:creator: MAX FISHER

item.title: 85 Years Later, Ukraine Marks Famine That Killed Millions
item.description: With each passing year, fewer witnesses to the tragedy of the Great Famine of 1932 and 1933, are still alive.
item.dc:creator: IULIIA MENDEL
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity

item.title: Retrieving Body of Missionary Killed on Remote Indian Island Is a Struggle
item.media:description: John Allen Chau, an American missionary, was killed last week as he tried to spread Christianity to North Sentinel, a forbidden island in the Andaman Sea with a long history of repelling outsiders.
item.description: John Allen Chau’s corpse has not been found. Those who have stepped ashore North Sentinel Island have been shot with bows and arrows.
item.dc:creator: JEFFREY GETTLEMAN, HARI KUMAR and KAI SCHULTZ

item.title: Mexico Mulls Allowing Migrants to Stay There Pending U.S. Asylum Bids
item.media:description: Leaders of the incoming Mexican government are planning to meet as early as Sunday to discuss options to cope with migrants at American border crossings.
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.description: President Trump insists that no migrant will be admitted to the U.S. without an approved asylum claim, but Mexico counters that no deal has been reached.
item.dc:creator: AZAM AHMED and KIRK SEMPLE

item.title: Taiwan’s President Quits as Party Chief After Stinging Losses in Local Races
item.media:description: Taiwan’s president, Tsai Ing-wen, center, resigned as leader of the Democratic Progressive Party.
item.description: With a presidential election only 14 months away, the results gave a big lift to the opposition Kuomintang, which favors closer ties with China.
item.dc:creator: CHRIS HORTON
item.category: Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships

item.title: Costly Raising of Argentine Submarine May Not Yield Answers or Bodies, Experts Say
item.media:description: Mirta Laz, 70, the mother of a crew member, Alberto Sánchez, earlier this week outside the naval base in Mar del Plata.
item.media:credit: Erica Canepa for The New York Times
item.description: Families of some of the 44 crew members who sank with the San Juan want it salvaged, but experts question the operation.
item.dc:creator: DANIEL POLITI

item.title: A Big New Airport Shows China’s Strengths (and Weaknesses)
item.media:description: Construction at Beijing-Daxing International Airport, designed by the Iraqi-British architect Zaha Hadid. It is scheduled to open next September.
item.description: Built in just five years, Beijing’s new airport will be one of the world’s largest. But it might not have been needed if the military hadn’t claimed most of China’s airspace.
item.dc:creator: IAN JOHNSON
